pr_title: RegExp - add case insensitive matching option

timeline.bodyText: Should it be new RegExp(regexPattern, RegExp.ALL | RegExp.CASE_INSENSITIVE) ?
timeline.author: jimczi
jimczi

replies.bodyText: The randomisation comes from the choice of string mutation later that produces the regex - this is just initialising the variable.
replies.author: markharwood

timeline.author: jimczi

timeline.bodyText: In order not to have a combinatorial explosion of the number of ctors, I think we could consider dropping this one: I think it's fine to require users to provide flags if they also want to configure case sensitivity?
timeline.author: jpountz

timeline.bodyText: same here, maybe it's fine to require passing syntax flags when you want to configure case sensitivity?
timeline.author: jpountz
jpountz

timeline.bodyText:
I think that this is incorrect as there is no 1:1 mapping between lowercase and uppercase letters, for instance ς and σ both have Σ as their uppercase variant. And if someone uses Σ in their regexes, ς wouldn't match as toLowerCase(Σ) returns σ.
Should we make this only about ASCII for now, like Java's Pattern class? https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/13/docs/api/java.base/java/util/regex/Pattern.html#CASE_INSENSITIVE We could add support for full Unicode later but this doesn't look like a low hanging fruit to me?
timeline.author: jpountz

replies.bodyText: good catch, +1 for ASCII only for now, I guess it was too ambitious to handle unicode in the first run
replies.author: jimczi

replies.bodyText: Would that be an argument for having a bit mask for case sensitivity flags instead of a Boolean? Java has the UNICODE_CASE flag which differs from the ASCII one and it might be an idea to leave something in the API open to future work.
replies.author: markharwood

replies.bodyText: So you mean having two bit mask flags, one for the operators and one for the matching behavior ?  I think that makes sense and could avoid complicating the ctrs in the future so +1.
replies.author: jimczi

replies.bodyText: Yes, that's what I was thinking
replies.author: markharwood

replies.bodyText: The one downside is RegExpQuery already has a (Term, int, int) constructor for syntax flags and maxDeterminizedStates so I added a (int, int, Term) variation for passing the syntax and match flags.
replies.author: markharwood

replies.bodyText:
An alternative would be an overhaul of RegExp.

Introducing a Builder class for the parser with named properties for settings
separating the RegExp parser logic from the  parsed objects (currently they are the same class).
separating rendering functions (toString, to Automaton, toStringTree) from the parsed objects.

I'm not sure if we're at the tipping point where all of that would make sense.
replies.author: markharwood

replies.bodyText:
so I added a (int, int, Term) variation for passing the syntax and match flags.

I am not sure this is clearer ;). It's not ideal but I prefer adding only one ctr (Term, int, int, int).
replies.author: jimczi

timeline.bodyText: I'd rather like a regular for loop, this is a bit abusing lambdas to my taste. :)
timeline.author: jpountz

timeline.bodyText: Let's call it CASE_INSENSITIVE since we want to leave the door for another flag that would control if unicode should be handled fully ?
timeline.author: jimczi

replies.bodyText: I thought it might be useful if the flag name reflected the current limitations?
replies.author: markharwood

replies.bodyText: But then what would be the other flag to allow unicode support ?
replies.author: jimczi

replies.bodyText:
UNICODE_CASE_INSENSITIVE or just CASE_INSENSITIVE?
Either way it would cover ASCII and all other UNICODE characters.
Admittedly slightly odd that the two flags overlap but the alternative is people may assume that a non-qualified name like "CASE_INSENSITIVE" would cover all the bases when we only currently support ASCII.
replies.author: markharwood

replies.bodyText: should we ensure that the flag is not used in the syntax_flags since we merge the two internally ?
replies.author: jimczi

replies.bodyText: My assumption was this class was lenient to syntax flags > 0xff before this change so should remain so for BWC reasons
replies.author: markharwood

timeline.bodyText: I don't think we need to maintain bw compat for this, is there any test that fails if you remove this line?

timeline.bodyText: In my opinion, all constructors should always take parameters in the same order. The current longest constructor does RegexpQuery(Term term, int syntaxFlags, AutomatonProvider provider, int maxDeterminizedStates), so I think that this one should be RegexpQuery(Term term, int syntaxFlags, int matchFlags, AutomatonProvider provider, int maxDeterminizedStates).

timeline.message: Changed case sensitive flag to a boolean in constructors.
Reduced visibility of case insensitive flag as a non-user-facing flag
Expose case sensitivity options in RegExpQuery
Addressed review comments - ASCII-only case changes, reduce num constructors and for loop tweak
Changed case sensitivity options to be a bit mask rather than a simple boolean to allow for future developments.

Addressed review comments (thanks @jpountz !)
Reordered constructor args and added arg validation.
